editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: REDDE DEBITVM. OR, A DISCOVRSE IN defence of three chiefe Fatherhoods, grounded upon a Text dilated to the Latitude of the Fift Commandement; and is therfore grounded thereupon, becau≈øe 'twas fir≈øt intended for the Pulpit, and ≈øhould have beene concluded in one or two Sermons.
BVT IS EXTENDED SINCE to a larger Tract; AND WRITTEN CHIEFELY in confutation of all di≈øobedient and factious kinde of People, who are enemies both to the Church, and State.
By JOHN SVVAN.

div.head: TO ALL SVCH FAMOVS WORTHIES as are both able, and zealous Patrons of the Church, and State, and of ≈øuch as endeavour the good thereof; Grace, Mercie, and Peace be multiplied from God our Father, and from the Lord Je≈øus Chri≈øt.
div.p:
THIS is a Piece which craves your Patronage. It containes nothing but what is ju≈øt and hone≈øt; and yet is like enough to meet with ≈øuch as ≈øhall oppo≈øe it: For I both know
and finde it true by experience, that hee who ≈øides not with the humours of the common multitude, incurres the odium of not a few. And indeed my comfort is, 'twas alwaies ≈øo: Ob≈øequium amicos, veritas odium parit. That great Apo≈øtle could have ≈øaid as much; Galae. 4.15.16. for whereas he remembers the good will that the Galatians once bore towards him, he findes the ca≈øe quite altered, and is now become their enemie, becau≈øe he telleth them what is truth: Not that he ever taught them other, but becau≈øe hee pre≈ø≈øeth the more earne≈øtly, where he fears or findes their reluctation. They had (as well appeareth) a minde to go a≈øtray; and he not yeelding to them, but directing otherwi≈øe, is ≈ølighted for his labour. But if it be good (as he al≈øo ≈øpeaketh) to be zealou≈øly affected alwaies in a good thing; 'tis fit that men ≈øubmit and learne with patience, till they come to the knowledge of what is good; otherwi≈øe their zeale cannot but be prepo≈øterous, and violent pa≈ø≈øions take place of true and
righteous informations. This is that which I only ayme at, a rectifying of ≈øuch as walke ami≈ø≈øe: and if herein my poore endeavours may but finde a curteous acceptation, I account my paines as much as nothing; being alwaies willing to promote what I can, the happie pro≈øperitie both of the Church and State. When therefore this Booke which I now ≈øend abroad, ≈øhall be ≈øo happie as to ki≈ø≈øe any of your hands; be plea≈øed to ≈øhelter it under the zealous wings of your favourable protection. And ≈øo praying God to ble≈ø≈øe you alwaies; I re≈øt devoted to do you the be≈øt ≈øervice that I can,

div.head: TO THE CHRISTIAN and courteous Reader.
div.p:
WElcome pro≈øperitie knowes not how to advance her ≈øtately Standard in any ≈øuch ≈øociety; which by means of faction and want of unitie, is mi≈øerably di≈ø-joynted. For, let the bodie be without ligaments, and it cannot ≈øtand; the joynts that ≈øhould helpe to uphold it, will be quickly broken: and ≈øo fatall ruine ≈øteps on too fa≈øt, and proclaimes that mi≈øchiefe, which for the want of concord, followes as an effect of ≈øuch a want. In con≈øideration whereof, my unfeigned wi≈øhes and good de≈øires have put me forward, to ca≈øt in one poore Mite among others, who are not onely joyfull and glad to ≈øee, but willing al≈øo to advance the de≈øired beautie, and happie pro≈øperitie both of the Church and State; who≈øe mutuall dependance is ≈øuch, that the welfare of the one, is the pro≈øperitie of the other, both helping to uphold the good of one another:
Whereto is pertinent that famous ≈øpeech of Gulielmus Occam, to Lewis the fift: Domine Imperator, defende me gladio, & ego te defendam calamo. Protect thou me with thy ≈øword Lord Emperor, and I will defend thee with my Pen. And indeed 'twas right. For as Mo≈øes, and Aaron were ≈øent together; and as the Prie≈øts of old were employed even inbidding battell to the enemie, and inquirie not ≈øeldome made at the mouth of the Prophets concerning affairs of the like nature: So ≈øhould ≈øtill the Church, and State be truly united each to other, and be mutuall upholders one of another.

Turbulent di≈øpo≈øitions wi≈øh well, I feare to neither; for with them, the troubled waters are the ≈øweeete≈øt ≈øtreames, and to kindle the fire of contentiou, their highe≈øt ayme. But farre be it from any ≈øonne of Peace, to have either his heart, tongue, or penne defiled with the filth of ≈øuch proceedings. Rather let it be the care of us all, not onely to marke them who cau≈øe divi≈øions, and avoyd them, as St. Paul directeth:Rom. 16.17. but to oppo≈øe what we can, the di≈øobedient di≈øturbers of this our I≈ørael. For if Saint Peter were re≈øi≈øted, when he tooke a wrong cour≈øe to knit well together the Jewes, Gala. 2.11.12.13. and the Gentiles; then let not others thinke it ≈øtrange, that in a way which is unwarrantable, they meete with ≈øuch as ≈øhall oppo≈øe them.

As for my ≈øefe, I know both mine owne ≈øtrength, and mine owne wants: It is little, I confe≈ø≈øe that I am able to doe; but am not therefore di≈øcouraged to
doe what I can. Saint Au≈øtine did as much (or more) in the Churches quarrell, as any Father of them all; and yet Saint Hierome was a better Lingui≈øt. There be diver ≈øitie of gifts,1 Cor. 12. ≈øayth the Apo≈øtle, but they proceed all from one Spirit, and are given al≈øo for one end: namely, for the edification or good of one another.

Reade therefore, and judge impartially, let byre≈øpect be ≈øet a≈øide: For though it oftentimes prevailes ≈øo farre with no few Readers, that according as they either valew or di≈ø-e≈øteeme the Author, they receive, or ≈ølight his writings; yet 'tis a fault, and faults we know mu≈øt bee amended; otherwi≈øe the wor≈øt mu≈øt needes be theirs who march unmindfull of their reckoning. Whereunto let me adde that which is al≈øo common; namely, That be a mans intentions never ≈øo ≈øincere, yet if the ≈øubject of his di≈øcour≈øe, be not agreeable to the ignorant fancies of every re≈øolved and ≈øelfe-will'd oppo≈øite, his bookes ≈øhall be either not read at all, or look't upon with a ≈øcornefull and ≈øupercilious eye; the la≈øh of cen≈øure not being wanting, where a prejudicate opinion bears the ≈øway. And this I may the rather mention, becau≈øe (among ≈øuch as the≈øe) I have ≈øomewhat felt in my former booke, the truth hereof: Yea, and have beene blamed al≈øo even for the very Title that I put unto it; that is to ≈øay, for giving it the name of Profano-Ma≈øtix. Which, how≈øoever di≈øta≈øted, cannot be ≈øo impertinent as ≈øome imagine: For rudene≈ø≈øe and irreverence, ≈øavours too much
of prophanation, which takes (I dare ≈øay) firme hold of them, who ob≈øtinately refu≈øe to wor≈øhippe God in the beautie of holine≈ø≈øe, notwith≈øtanding there be manife≈øt proofes for ≈øuch a practice. And for their ≈øakes it is, that I chiefely prefixed ≈øo ≈ømart a title; which to others of a better temper, may be mitigated to a more milde and gentle meaning; ≈øerving onely as a caution to let them know, that they might be more zealous of Gods glory, if they were le≈ø≈øe indifferent, and more forward to manife≈øt their inward feare and reverence, by their outward devotion: for ≈øo ≈øhall they glorifie God, both in their ≈øoules, and in their bodies; even as they looke to have both partake in the heavenly joyes of the life to come: At which Saint Paul hath plainly pointed, in the 1 Cor. 6.20. Nor is it but certaine that a reward pre≈øuppo≈øeth a worke: If therefore we live in hope of an happie re≈øurrection; why then doe we exempt our bodies from the ≈øervice of God, and lay the totall of this dutie upon the ≈øoule? Or if we know that the happine≈ø≈øe of the ≈øoule ≈øeparate from the bodie, neither is, nor ≈øhall be con≈øummate, till the bodie be againe united to it, Why doe we not for the pre≈øent joyne both together; and grant, that as the outward wor≈øhip, without the inward is but dead, ≈øo the inward without the outward is incompleat, even as is that happine≈ø≈øe alreadie mentioned?

I will not be tedious to adde any more, ≈øave only this: The di≈øcour≈øe now tendred, de≈øires thee (good
Reader) to be taken up, as an expo≈øition of the fir≈øt Precept in the Second Table. For though it be grounded upon a Text in Salomon, yet my acceptation of of it, aymes chiefely at ≈øuch a latitude, as may not cau≈øe it to be excluded, from out the bounds of the Fift Commandement, but ≈øuffer it to be con≈øidered in a Cateche≈øticall way. Farewell.

q.p: There is is a generation that cur≈øeth their Father, and doth not ble≈ø≈øe their Mother.

div.p: THis text in generall is the declaration of an offence, wherein we have two parts. The fir≈øt is a Denomination of the parties offending: The ≈øecond is an expre≈ø≈øion of the particularities of their offence.
The denomination is in the word generation for (≈øaith the Text) There is a generation.

The offence is twofold. Fir≈øt, that they cur≈øe: Secondly, that they doe not ble≈ø≈øe. For as there is a generation, ≈øo there is even ≈øuch a generation as cur≈øeth their father and doth not ble≈ø≈øe their Mother.

Concerning the fir≈øt of which, there lurkes
(perhaps) ≈øome ambiguity in the word generation. I ≈øhall by degrees therefore unfold or explicate what a generation is, together with the kinds thereof, that thereby it may appeare what the text meaneth by ≈øaying, There is a generation.
A Generation is either in re≈øpect of ≈øucce≈ø≈øion, or in re≈øpect of qualities.
That of ≈øucce≈ø≈øion is either generall or in more particular.

The Generall hath re≈øpect to the ≈øucceeding times of all ages and all per≈øons in every nation under heaven. Thus were the chronologicall periods of time, and ages of the world, Generations: as from the Creation to the Floud; from the Floud to the Promi≈øe; from the Promi≈øe to the Law; from the Law to the Temple; from the Temple to the captivity; from the captivity to Chri≈øt; from Chri≈øt to us; and from us to the end of the world. Or (if they be accounted according to that di≈øtinction of 6. Ages, wherein men ≈øuffer the labours and travells of this pre≈øent world) they are from the Creation to the Floud, from the Floud to Abraham; from Abraham to David; from David to the captivity: from the captivity to Chri≈øt; and from Chri≈øt to the end of the world. The≈øe are the generall.

The more particular were pertinent either to ≈øome one nation, or to a private de≈øcent of particular
families. Of the fir≈øt of the≈øe in the Go≈øpell it is ≈øaid that This generation ≈øhall not pa≈ø≈øe till all bee fulfilled, And of the ≈øecond,L ‚Ä¢ k. 21.32. in the P≈øalmi≈øt thus we read,P≈øal. 109.12 that In the next generation his name ≈øhall be cleane put out, which (if we re≈øpect the time) is ≈øeldome or never more then an hundred yeares;Gen. 15.13.16. as is witne≈ø≈øed by that of Mo≈øes [in Gen. 15.] where we read of foure generations in the compa≈ø≈øe or ≈øpace of foure hundred yeares.

Now becau≈øe a generation in the≈øe large extents produce a diver≈øity of factions, and ≈øeverall multitudes of di≈øpo≈øitions, ≈øome following the ≈øtreame of one thing, ≈øome another, it is that I have ≈øecondly ob≈øerved another kind of generation: viz. in re≈øpect of qualities. And unto this the text adhereth as mo≈øt pertinent, for that's a generation in re≈øpect of quality, wherin a race, Sect, or company of people follow either the doing of that which is good, or the doing of that which is bad.

The fir≈øt of which is a generation not ≈øo much pure in their owne eyes as in Gods. The ≈øecond is a froward perver≈øe and crooked generation; from which (as the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeaketh) every good Chri≈øtian mu≈øt ≈øave him≈øelfe. The kinds of the≈øe perver≈øe or crooked ones are many and among the re≈øt, this in the text is one, and as one, ≈øo none of the be≈øt, For There is a generation that cur≈øeth their father, and doth not ble≈ø≈øe
their mother. And thus much of the denomination of the offenders,
2 Their offence followeth, and it is two fold. Fir≈øt, that they cur≈øe. Secondly, that they doe not ble≈ø≈øe.

The fir≈øt is a ≈øinne of commi≈ø≈øion: The ≈øecond of omi≈ø≈øion: the one commits the evill he ≈øhould not do; the other omits the good that he ≈øhould doe: And ≈øo (like erring ≈øheepe) both have wandred and gone a≈øtray.

In the commi≈ø≈øive part the ≈øinne of the generation is ≈øet downe po≈øitively. In the omi≈ø≈øive privatively. Or in the commi≈ø≈øive part there is the act and the object. The Act is cur≈øing: The object is the father.

The Act, in it ≈øelfe ≈øingle and alone, is bad enough: but is made ≈øo much the wor≈øe by rea≈øon of the circum≈øtances, or by rea≈øon of that ≈øpeciall object at which it aymeth. For ≈øuch relation as is between the Father and the Sonne; ≈øuch (yea the ≈øame) is between this Act or and his Object.

The omi≈ø≈øive part affords an object al≈øo, but 'tis detained in the privation of ≈øuch an act, as of right ≈øhould looke towards, and not from it; for although the power of a Father be in many re≈øpects greater then the power of a Mother; yet (as ≈øaith Chemnitius) there mu≈øt be an exequation of dutie and honour,Chemnit. in Loc. as well to the one as to the other; as well to the inferiour as the no bler
≈øexe; as well to the weaker as the ≈øtronger ve≈ø≈øell. Neither are ≈øinnes of omi≈ø≈øion (in knowne duties) but every way as bad (nay rather wor≈øe) then ≈øinnes of commi≈ø≈øion. So that if it be a ≈øin to cur≈øe the Father, it mu≈øt needs bee no le≈ø≈øe not to ble≈ø≈øe the mother.

But who are they to whom this right belongs? Are they onely ≈øuch, as in re≈øpect of being,The ≈øummo & extention of the Text. begat and brought us forth? My an≈øwer mu≈øt be negative, for the text wil beare it, as well as that of the 5. Commandement. Give mee leave therefore, in as plaine a method as I can to ≈øet before your eyes, not onely the≈øe, but even the ≈øeverall ≈øorts of other parents, which in a peevi≈øh, perver≈øe and crooked Generation, are rather cur≈øed then ble≈ø≈øed, di≈øhonoured then honoured, de≈øpi≈øed then cheri≈øhed, contemned then obeyed, with a thou≈øand other ≈øuch de≈øperate dealings, which a wicked generation ca≈øts upon them.

And indeed to take up the matter aright, it mu≈øt needs be a true conclu≈øion that it can be but a lame and a di≈øobedient dutie, to acknowledge none to be our parents but tho≈øe who begat and brought us forth. For, although I ≈øpeake nothing of ma≈øters, who are Patres familias, 2 Kin. 5.13. Fathers of a family, or although I ≈øpeake nothing of the Aged who are Elders, and mu≈øt bee honoured as fathers.1 Tim. 5.1.2. Although (I ≈øay) nothing be ≈øpoken of the≈øe, or of ≈øome others which by

way of eminency have a prerogative that pleads for their honour, we have be≈øides them, yea and be≈øides our Natural parents al≈øo, even fathers of the Church, and of the common wealth. And therefore they are not onely our parents who give us a beeing; but ≈øuch al≈øo as give vs a ≈øafe and well-being. Our naturall parents give us the fir≈øt: Our politicall parents give us the ≈øecond: And from our ≈øpirituall parents we receive the third or la≈øt which is the perfection of all the re≈øt.

Now, if to give the fir≈øt bee ≈øomething; then ≈øomething ≈øure it needs mu≈øt be to give or uphold the ≈øecond; and if the ≈øecond then the next. That is, If hee who gives the fir≈øt being mu≈øt have honour and the like: then hee who gives the ≈øecond: And if this be due to the fir≈øt and ≈øecond, then al≈øo to the third.

Neither ≈øecondly can I thinke, that a mans fir≈øt being is as any thing to him if he wants the next: that is, if he bee oppre≈ø≈øed by the mighty and finds no comforter. For what a poore thing it is to bee without a deliverer from the hard u≈øage of wicked men, Solomon declareth in the fourth chapter of Eccle≈øia≈øtes, at the fir≈øt, ≈øecond, and third ver≈øes.

Or thirdly, having both the≈øe and wanting that which is the in≈øtrumentall cau≈øe of the be≈øt or la≈øt, is to bee without the happine≈ø≈øe of that which is ≈øure to crowne even the ≈øecond and fir≈øt. For ≈øaith our Saviour concerning Iudas,
Woe be to that man by whom the Sonne of man is betrayed, Math. 26.24. it had beene good for that man if hee had never beene borne. Intimating, that the not being of a creature is farre better then the ill being e≈øpecially when the end, which ≈øhould crowne the act, mu≈øt abide for ever in the never ending ≈øadne≈ø≈øe of a ≈øad cata≈øtrophe.

And therefore as wee may not cur≈øe, revile harme, contemne, or de≈øpi≈øe tho≈øe from whom wee have our fir≈øt being; So neither may wee revile, harme, cur≈øe, contemne, or de≈øpi≈øe tho≈øe from whom we have either our ≈øafe, or our well-being. For, as thou art a man, it is that thou honoure≈øt thy naturall father, and as a member of a politicall bodie or ≈øocietie, thou can≈øt not but honour thy civill father: yea, and as a Chri≈øtian (which is more then a man) thou mu≈øt likewi≈øe ≈øee that thou honour thy Spirituall, Eccle≈øia≈øticall, or Gho≈øtly father.

Thy naturall parent is Gods in≈øtrument for thy naturall being: Thy prince Gods in≈øtrument for thy ≈øafe, quiet & civill being; and thy pa≈øtor Gods in≈øtrument for thy ≈øpiritual, well and holy being. Without the fir≈øt thou coulde≈øt not be any thing. Without the ≈øecond thou coulde≈øt not be ≈øafely what thou art: And without the next, thou could≈øt not be what thou woulde≈øt. For as the ≈øword of the civill Governour keepes thee from the forreigne and dome≈øticke power of ≈øuch wicked builders and bloody hunters, as were Cain
and Nimrod: So the ≈øword of Gods Mini≈øter keepeth thee from the ≈ønatching pawes of Sathan, that ≈øworn enemy of all mankind,1 Pet. 5.8. who (like a roaring Lyon) ramps up and downe, ≈øeeking whom he may devoure.

The≈øe then are the chiefe Fatherhoods of greate≈øt note: the one wherof may be no more cur≈øed then the other, nor the other le≈ø≈øe ble≈ø≈øed then the fir≈øt. div.head: CHAP. III.

Which cannot but be a condemnation to all them, who neglect the true Mini≈øters of Gods word, as ≈øome have noted upon that Text. In a word,Alexand. ab Alexandro, lib. 2. c. 8. ≈øuch was their honour, that as from the Philo≈øophers they cho≈øe their Prie≈øts; ≈øo out of their Prie≈øts, they cho≈øe or made their Kings. And againe, to looke among other Nations, the fir≈øt Kings of the Romans were Prie≈øts: The Emperours afterwards would be Pontifices Maximi. Tull. lib. 2. De legih. And the Augurs (≈øayth Tullie) were chiefe in the Common-werle. The Flamines, and other Prie≈øts were of no meane account.Cae≈ø. com. lib. 6. Here al≈øo with Us, and in France, the Druides were of great e≈øteeme among the chiefe ranks of honour: To which al≈øo adde, that our Aunce≈øtours of latter times, accounted none to be Milites legitimi; who had not fir≈øt offered their ≈øwords upon the Altar, and received their con≈øecration to the trade of warre, from the Bi≈øhop or Prie≈øt of their place; B. Hall. which is al≈øo a cau≈øe why it ≈øtill is, that ≈øome orders of Knighthood (≈øayth one) are held religious. And indeed, ≈øeeing all Nobilitie came at the fir≈øt from the Pen, or the Pike; Dr. Boy≈øe. that is from Learning, or Chivalrie, as another ≈øpeaketh; there is a plea for the Scholler, as well as the Souldier, and con≈øequently for the Divine; and for him chiefely in his profe≈ø≈øion above the re≈øt, becau≈øe Divinitie is the mo≈øt excellent,
no other ≈øtudie or profe≈ø≈øion being fit to be compared with it.

But if all this bee able to move you nothing, ca≈øt (I be≈øeech you) your eyes from hence to a better light, to the ≈øacred ≈øheetes of holy Scripture, and there ob≈øerve what Gods Spirit hath recorded. And fir≈øt I ≈øhall ≈øhew you, that the Iewes were e≈øteemed to mur ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ urre again≈øt the Lord, yea, and to de≈øpi≈øe the Lord; when they murmured again≈øt Mo≈øes, and Aaron, and made but a ≈ømall account of tho≈øe his ≈øervants: For ≈øo you may read in Exod. 16.7. Numb. 16.11.1 Sam. 8.8. and chap. 26.9. And to Samuel (≈øaith God) They have not de≈øpi≈øed thee, but mee: E≈øay 57. & Ezek. 3.7. Luke 10.16. And in the Prophecies of E≈øay, and Ezekiel 'tis recorded; that whil'≈øt the people jeered at the Prophets, they reproached God. Chri≈øt al≈øo taketh the wrong done to his Me≈ø≈øengers, as done to him≈øelfe. For who hath not heard it, that who ≈øo de≈øpi≈øeth us that bee ≈øent, de≈øpi≈øeth Chri≈øt? and if Chri≈øt bee de≈øpi≈øed, then al≈øo God. For hee that de≈øpi≈øeth you (≈øayth our Saviour) de≈øpi≈øeth mee; and hee that de≈øpi≈øeth mee, de≈øpi≈øeth him that ≈øent me. As on the contrary, he that receiveth you, receiveth me; and he that receiveth me, receiveth him that ≈øent me, as it is in Luke 10.16, and in Math. 9.41. Hee that receiveth a Prophet in the name of a Prophet, ≈øhall have a Prophets reward: And in the 1. Cor. 14.1. it is the Doctrine of Saint Paul, that men e≈øteeme of their Mini≈øters,
as of the Amba≈ø≈øadours of Chri≈øt: And in another place,1 The≈ø. 5.12. Know them (≈øayth he) which labour among you, and are over you in the Lord. Which knowledge hee al≈øo explaineth, andVer≈øe 13. ≈øheweth, it not to be a ≈øcornefull kinde of knowledge, ≈øuch as is in many; who in contempt and deri≈øion can ≈øay, Loe, yonder goes a Prie≈øt, that man's a Divine, &c. But ≈øuch a knowledge [reade the place] as carries with it a reverent e≈øteeme and regard: and this not after a meane manner neither, but after an eminent or high manner; yea, ≈øayth he, let it be „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ; that is, ≈øuper exabundanti; or in Engli≈øh very highly; nor this out of con≈øtraint, or through feare, but out of love. All which hee further ≈øheweth, mu≈øt be, if for no other cau≈øe, yet for this; namely, for their workes ≈øake: that is, vel co nomine, even in regard of their holy function, wherein they are ≈øet apart to be the men of God,2 Cor. 6.1. Chri≈øts Amba≈ø≈øadours, and ≈øuch labourours as labour among you for your edification,Ephe≈ø. 5.30. into that my≈øticall bodie of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus.

Out of which Seripture (≈øeeing the Apo≈øtle ≈øpeakes ≈øo generally) 'tis ea≈øie to learne, that in ca≈øe the Heralds booke (as ≈øome have ≈øcornfully objected) ≈øhould either denie, or be ≈øparing of civill honour, to tho≈øe of our Tribe, who are not able to derive their pedigree from renowned Aunce≈øtours. Gods booke is of u≈øe to ≈øupply even that defect; for we ≈øee that the booke of
God neither denieth, nor is ≈øparing of any ≈øuch thing to us; but would have us knowne with re≈øpect, and not meanely e≈øteemed, but bee of high account in regard of that office whereunto we are called. And whereas againe the≈øe pratlers ≈øpeake of ≈øpirituall honour, which they ≈øay they are willing to be≈øtow upon us; I wonder what's their meaning! I am ≈øure they will not wor≈øhip us, nor is there cau≈øe why wee ≈øhould de≈øire it. But bee their meaning what it will, that which they grant us mu≈øt appeare, or el≈øe in conclu≈øion they grant us nothing. And indeed, that I may not flatter them, they ≈øtand ≈øo much upon ≈øpirit, in the re≈øpects which they owe to God, and his Mini≈øters; that it may well bee feared they decline from truth in either of both, let them prate, or prattle to the contrary what they plea≈øe.

And from whence comes all this? doth it not proceed from the ambitious hearts, and ≈øwelling mindes of the proud emulatours, ignorant, rude contemners, and irreligious de≈øpi≈øers among the Laitie? I beleeve it doth; for the≈øe things chiefely are the prime roots, or cau≈øes, why Corah, and his company live ≈øtill among us; and why the ≈øpirit of tho≈øe dead Children (taught by their wor≈øer Fathers) who mocked the Prophet, breathes ≈øtill in the brea≈øts of our oppo≈øers. But why may not two She-Beares,2 King. 2.24. or ≈øome wor≈øe puni≈øhment light upon them? Shall a
judgement ≈øeize upon ≈øome, and will not others be warned? Saint Au≈øtine ≈øayth, The Children were ≈øtrucken, that their elders might bee taught. For when the pride of the Iewes was growne extravagant, and that the very Children could ≈øcoffe at the Prophets; the holy Spirit was grieved, and the Children torne in peeces. Vt percu≈ø≈øis parvulis, majores reciperent di≈øciplinam;
St. Augu≈øt. de Temp. Se ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ . 204.
& mors filiorum, fieret di≈øciplina Parentum, & Prophetam, quem mirabilia facientem nolebant amare, di≈øcerent vel timere. And if ≈øo, then why doe the≈øe mad people ≈øtrive to let the world bee witne≈ø≈øe, that they care not for the Scriptures, although they ≈øpeake both by precepts, and examples? Certes if they had any true regard to what is written in them; they would ≈øurcea≈øe at the la≈øt to di≈ø-re≈øpect us, and not labour ≈øtill to have our heads tyed under their girdles. Bee not deceived, God is not mocked. It were a wrong to our callings (and ≈øo to that ≈øacred Maje≈øtie from whom we are ≈øent) to dance attendance on proud contemner, or to yeeld with willingnes to ≈øuch ≈øervilitie. Hertofore theHier. tradi ‚Ä¢ . in Gene≈ø. fir≈øt borne had the right of Prie≈øthood; but now the world ≈øtrives to make Prie≈øts of younger brothers, and younger brothers of the Prie≈øts. Repentance may come when it is too late, and therefore learne betimes to know God's Mini≈øters.

I goe not about to finde fault with all, wee have no ≈øuch ill mea≈øure (God bee thanked) at
every ones hands. Howbeit, this is a theame which I might extend to that which many (and they perhaps ≈øuch as are u≈øually accounted the be≈øt in a Pari≈øh) would be loth to heare it. But I forbeare them all, and ≈øhall rather make my inlargement, by ≈øetting down the pious patterns of holy Chri≈øtians; who like the true ≈øervants of God, have honoured his Me≈ø≈øengers.

And fir≈øt I will begin with the Galatians, Gala. 4.14.15. of whom it is written, that they received Saint Paul as an Angell of God; yea, even as Chri≈øt Ie≈øus: and would if it had beene po≈ø≈øible, have pulled out their owne eyes,Aug. homil. de Pa≈øloribus, inter opera Hierom. to have done him good. And yet (as one ≈øpeaketh) accedit ad ovem languidam, adovem putridam, ≈øecare vul ‚Ä¢ us, non parcere putredini: that is, He came to a ≈øick and an infected ≈øheep; to launce the wound, not to ≈øpare the rottennes.

Thus al≈øo did the Carthaginians, Dieteri ‚Ä¢ . ex Vict. de Per≈øecut. vandalic. lib. 2. who (as Victor relateth) were ≈øo well affected toward Eugenius their Bi≈øhop, that (if it might have beene) every each one of them would have layd downe their lives to have redeemed his.

And as for the noble Matrons of Rome, 'tis thus recorded: That when their Bi≈øhop Liberius was bani≈øhed, becau≈øe he would not condemne that holy man Athana≈øius; Theod. lib. 2. cap. 17. being ruled by the advice of their husbands, they came to the Emperour Con≈øtantius, being cloathed with their mo≈øt precious ornaments; and de≈øired that he would re≈øtore againe their Bi≈øhop, and take
pitty of ≈øo great a Citie, which (being deprived of her Pa≈øtour) was expo≈øed to the treacheries of devouring wolves.
Nay more, for even that famous Con≈øtantine; under whom the Church began to flouri≈øh, u≈øed the Clergie with no meane re≈øpect. Neither did the pious Princes after him but remember it.

Yea, and thus al≈øo did the godly Kings and Princes before Chri≈øt. They honoured the Prophets, Prie≈øts, and Levites with an high regard, had them in great price; and (which in the≈øe dayes is mo≈øt envied) cho≈øe from among them ≈øuch as ≈øhould be employed in matters of State, be Iudges, and Iu≈øtices in Courts of civill affaires; the High-Prie≈øt being alwaies the ≈øecond man in their Kingdome.

And that the≈øe were be≈øt able in matters of greate≈øt difficultie to bee thus employed, read God's owne Sanction in Deut. 17.18.See al≈øo what God had appointed concerning this, in Deut. 21.5. If there ari≈øe a matter too hard for thee in judgement, &c. then ≈øhalt thou ari≈øe and goe unto the place which the Lord thy God ≈øhall chu≈øe; and thou ≈øhalt come to the Prie≈øts of the Levites, and to the Iudge that ≈øhall hee in tho≈øe dayes, and aske; and they ≈øhall ≈øhew thee the ≈øentence of judgement. Upon which ground, David ≈øetting the Kingdome in better order then in proce≈ø≈øe of time it was growne into,1 Chro. 23.4. appointed ≈øixe thou≈øand Levites to bee Indges, and Magi≈øtrates over the people: and beyond Iordan towards the We≈øt,1 Chron. 26.30. a thou≈øand
and ≈øeven hundred, both to ≈øerve God in the place of Levites, and al≈øo to ≈øerve the King in offices of State.ibid. ver≈øe 32. Hee al≈øo ≈øet two thou≈øand and ≈øeven hundred to bee over the Tribes of Ruben, Gad, and Mana≈ø≈øeth, to heare and determine in cau≈øes, both Eccle≈øia≈øticall, and Civill.
The like al≈øo did Ieho≈øophat in his reformation of the Church and Common-weale.2 Chron. 19.5.8.11.

Ezra was a Prie≈øt,Ezr. c. 7. & 8. yet who but he that fir≈øt of all after the Captivitie, ordered all matters both for the Church,Nehe. c. 1. and State. Nehemiah came not up untill 13. yeares after; for Nehemiah was in the twentieth, and Ezra in the 7. yeare of Artaxerxes. Zorobabel I grant was long before; but he did little or nothing for the reducing of things into a forme of government; or ≈øuppo≈øe he did, Ezra we are ≈øure did a great deale more.

Neither was it,1 Sam. c. 2.18 &c. 7.15.16. but that (even before all the≈øe) Samuel as a Prie≈øt mini≈øtered before the Lord in a linnen Ephod, and as a Iudge did ride his circuit every yeare, over all the land: yea, and in the daies of Saul, although he was the annointed King; yet Samuel ruled joyntly with him ≈øo long as they lived each with other: or at the lea≈øt was ≈øuch a Coun≈øeller to him, as that after hee was dead and buried, he ≈øeeks to heare what he would advi≈øe, or an≈øwer, ≈øtanding then de≈øtitute of ≈øuch direction as he had u≈øually received from him.

Nay ≈øooner yet, for Phineas was ≈øent Amba≈ø≈øadour to proclaim war again≈øt the Rubenites, & the
Gadites, & the half tribe of Mana≈ø≈øes. Io≈øh. 22.12.3.
The Prie≈øts overthrew the Citie Iericho, Io≈øh. 6. Nor did they afterwards but ≈øound their Trumpets, and bid the battell in the warre of Ahiiah again≈øt Ieroboam. 2 Chron. 13.12.14.
The land al≈øo is divided among the Tribes, by Eleazar, and Io≈øhua. Numb. 34.17.

A thou≈øand likewi≈øe of every Tribe is ≈øent out to war again≈øt the Midianites, under the conduct of Phineas, Numb. 31.6. And in the ≈øame warre, the ≈øpoyles were divided among the Souldiers, by Mo≈øes, and Eleazar the Prie≈øt, and the cheife Fathers of the Congregation. ver≈øe 26.
The people al≈øo were numbred by Mo≈øes, and Eleazar in the plaine of Moab; as they had been numbred formerly by Mo≈øes, and Aaron in the wilderne≈ø≈øe of Sinai, Numb. 26.63.64.

From which te≈øtimonies it is plaine and manife≈øt, that ≈øome ≈øuch Prie≈øts as the King thinks fit, may (when he plea≈øeth) be lawfully employed in civill affaires or offices; and may even thus be honoured, as were tho≈øe Prie≈øts of old.

And whereas ≈øome object, that arguments drawne from the old. Te≈øtament,An objection an≈øwered. prove nothing now under the New: it is an≈øwered. Fir≈øt, that they may as well deny the arguments taken from thence again≈øt the Popes authority, and domineering power over Chri≈øtian Kings, and Princes, as denie the≈øe arguments, for proofe of that civill honour which is thus
given to the Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpell. And therefore it is not love, but envie, which would ≈øeeme to bol≈øter out things with ≈øuch new Divinitie.

Secondly, the Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpell (as one hath well ob≈øerved) may with more convenience be employed in civill offices, then tho≈øe Prie≈øts under the Law; who≈øe time is not now taken up (as then it was) with attendance on the daily ≈øacrifices; great number of fea≈øts, ≈øolemnities, and ≈øuch like occa≈øions, by which their lei≈øure was le≈ø≈øe to heare civill matters, then now to the Mini≈øter under the Go≈øpell.

Thirdly, the Mini≈øters of the Go≈øpell have ≈øucceeded in a place of the Levites, and looke what in that kinde was lawfull for them to doe, is not unlawfull now, e≈øpecially ≈øeeing the≈øe employments pertained not to things typicall, figurative, or ceremoniall. And fourthly, although Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles were never thus employed, yet is that nothing again≈øt our tenet: For who made me a judge over you, ≈øayth Chri≈øt? Intimating,Luke 12.14. that unle≈ø≈øe the ≈øupreame Magi≈øtrate ≈øhall a≈ø≈øigne Clergie-men to ≈øuch offices, they may not meddle with them. But had the Church and Common-wealth been both one, then it had beene as lawfull as in the daies of old; which appointment or a≈ø≈øignation was never like to bee, ≈øo long as the Church was in the Kingdome of heathen tyrants.

Certain it is, that when the Emperours became Chri≈øtians, ≈øome men of the Church were thus employed. And although the condition of the Mini≈øters of Chri≈øt, differed not in this from that of the Levites, yet it could not ≈øhew it ≈øelfe till then. Examples are not wanting.Theod. lib. 2. c. 30.
Theodorit. makes mention of one Iames Bi≈øhop ofCalled al≈øo Ny≈øibit.
Antioch in Mygdonia, who ≈øhined with Apo≈øtolicall grace; and yet was both Bi≈øhop, and governour of the afore≈øaid Citie.
Or if this te≈øtimonie be ob≈øcure, ≈øee another; Saint Ambro≈øe was twice employed in the office of an Amba≈ø≈øadour, by the Emperour Valentinian, and not without good ≈øucce≈ø≈øe.

Socrates al≈øo makes mention of one Marutha, Socrat. lib. 7. c. ‚Ä¢ . Bi≈øhop of Me≈øopotamia, whom the Emperour of Rome ≈øent in an Amba≈ø≈øage to the King of Per≈øia; which employment likewi≈øe proved good, both to the Church, and Common-weale.

Neither can this bee called an inua≈øion of the offices of the civill Magi≈øtrate, or be contrary to the rule of any auncient Canon, when it is done by the con≈øent and appointment of the chiefe Magi≈øtrate; as in the lawes of Iu≈øtinian (alledged by Saravia) is apparent.Lib. de honore Pra≈øulibus et Pre≈øbyt. debito. cap. 20. And although the the Popes lawes have decreed the contrary; yet it is not fit (≈øayth one) that we which are a reformed Church, and have long ≈øince abandoned the Popes authority,Dr Dove of Church govern. pag. 40. ≈øhould now for≈øake God and the examples of the holy Bible, to follow
the Pope, and his Canons.

Fiftly, and la≈øtly, Saint Paul thought it lawfull to ≈øpend his ≈øpare time in the worke of his hands: But if the nece≈ø≈øitie of Dome≈øticke affaires may excu≈øe a Pa≈øtour of the Church for ≈øo doing; then much more may they be excu≈øed for doing ≈øuch offices (when the King thinkes it fit that they bee called thereunto) as ≈øhall benefit the common wealth wherein they live.

Neither doth this appertaine to the entangling of our ≈øelves with the things of this World. For that text where this is mentioned; ≈øtriketh at tho≈øe who≈øe covetous hands and greedie hearts are ≈øo glewed to the earth, for the gathering to them≈øelves a private e≈øtate, that they forget every ≈øuch thing as may tend to the good, either of the Church, or State wherein they live; which every good Chri≈øtian, and therefore every upright man of God will be carefull to avoid.

Nor againe, doth that of our Saviour [in Luke 22.25.] denie the titles of civill honours to men of the Church. Titles of civill honour are not their denied; for it doth not (as ≈øhall appeare) forbid honour and authority, or the titles thereunto belonging: but ambitious ≈øeeking of it, or them; together with that tyrannicall u≈øing of it, which the wicked kings of the Nations, through the conceit of their owne greatne≈ø≈øe, and ≈øoothings of their flatterers proudly take upon them.
And that this is the meaning of that Text, appeareth by the≈øe rea≈øons.

Fir≈øt, becau≈øe Chri≈øt acknowledged that the title Rabbi (which ≈øignifieth a Ma≈øter, an honourable per≈øon, or a man that is eminent by rea≈øon of his many dignities and places of honour that he holdeth) was a title of right belonging to him: Hee di≈øclaimed it not, but embraced it. Ye call mee Ma≈øter, and Lord, and ye ≈øay well, for ≈øo I am. Iohn 13.13.
Secondly, Iohn Bapti≈øt was called Ma≈øter, and not refu≈øed it. Luke 3.12.

Thirdly, although Saint Paul, and Barnabas Act. 14.15. denied to be wor≈øhipped with Divine honour; yet when Paul, and Silas were reverenced with civill honour, and called „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ [Lords] by the Ma≈øter of the Pri≈øon, they made no ≈øcruple of it, but onely ≈øayd; Beleeve in the Lord Ie≈øus, and thou ≈øhalt be ≈øaved. Fourthly, the change of Abram, to Abraham; and of Sarai, to Sarah witne≈ø≈øe no le≈ø≈øe: for their names being thus changed, were not onely a token of confirming the promi≈øe; but al≈øo an honourable favour which God him≈øelfe vouch≈øafed to them, Dr. Willet ex Mercer. in Gen. for their greater grace and re≈øpect among tho≈øe with whom they lived; as was ≈øeene when Abraham communed with the Children of Heth; who an≈øwering, ≈øayd unto him: Heare us my Lord, thou art a mighty Prince among us. Gen. 23.6. And God al≈øo told Abimilech,
that he was a Prophet. Gen. 20.7.
Fiftly, becau≈øe when Obadiah met Elias, he fell on his face, and ≈øayd; Art thou my Lord Elias? He an≈øwered, yea; Goe and tell thy Lord, behold, Elias is here. 1 Kings 18.7.8.
Sixtly, becau≈øe Eli≈øha accepted of the like title, as it is in the 2 Kings 4.16.

In which regard Beza noted not ami≈ø≈øe upon the≈øe words [in Mat. 23.8.] Bee not yee called Rabbi, &c. Ne vocemini, id est, Ne ambiatis. Bee not ye called; that is, doe not ambitiou≈øly ≈øeeke after that title, or pride your ≈øelves in it: for otherwi≈øe our Sauiour doth not accept again≈øt any, either for not denying the titles of their office, or for not refu≈øing the honour due unto them. And here an end of this Section.

div.head: SECT. II.
div.p: THE next thing that followeth, is, That the people give eare, and come where they may heare the Doctrines, rebukes, and exhortations of their gho≈øtly Fathers. For though they be men whom the Lord hath a≈ø≈øigned to this holy office: yet men, to whom hee hath conveighed a peculiar grace,2 Tim. 1.6. ibid. which the Orthodox and right do ≈øo ≈øtirre up, that when they preach, they preach not them≈øelves, but Ie≈øus Chri≈øt. 2 Cor. 4.5. Heb. 5.4. They have power to officiate, but they take it not; it is given them before they have it. It came to tho≈øe of Chri≈øts ≈øchoole, from Chri≈øt him≈øelfe; but was not to end with them, for there is a * building which cannot be perfected without it: And being therefore appointed for it,Ephe≈ø 4.12. Mat. 28. ult. it hath beene conveighed ever ≈øince by the impo≈øition of hands, to ≈øuch as are not otherwi≈øe any lawfull Prie≈øts of God. And finally, that care may be had in the conveighance hereof; It is the coun≈øell of Saint Paul to Timothie, 1 Tim. 5.22. That he lay hands upon no man ≈øuddenly.

Thus then we have it, and are by this meanes become per≈øons ≈øacred, and have authoritie to deale in holy things. We ble≈ø≈øe in the name of him that ble≈ø≈øeth: The di≈øpen≈øation of the Word and Sacraments is committed to us; We have power to binde,Mat. 18.18. 2 Cor. 5.20. wee have power to loo≈øe, wee are Amba≈ø≈øadours for Chri≈øt, as though God did be≈øeech you by us.

The me≈ø≈øage is from Heaven, as delivering to you God's ble≈ø≈øed will, out of his holy Word: And therefore to be received,1 The≈ø≈ø. 2.13 not as the word of men, but as the Word of God. So that as we, if we love the Lord,Ioh. 21.15.16 will feede his Lambes, and Sheepe: In like manner ye, if ye de≈øpi≈øe not Chri≈øt,Luke 21.16. Acts 7.51. nor re≈øi≈øt the holy Gho≈øt; will be content to hearken to the words of tho≈øe by whom he ≈øpeaketh.

div.head: SECT. III.

Saint Paul, I confe≈ø≈øe ≈øpeaketh to the Romans; Let not him that eateth, de≈øpi≈øe him that eateth not: and let not him that eateth not, judge him that eateth. Rom. 14.3. And now al≈øo ≈øecondly,An an≈øwer to the 2d objection. whereas ≈øome make doubt of the lawfulnes of Spirituall juri≈ødiction, or Courts Eccle≈øia≈øticall: I think there is enough in the former an≈øwer, to yeeld ≈øatisfaction even in this, here therefore I ≈øhall need to ≈øay the le≈ø≈øe. of God by his holy Prophet;E≈øay 5.18.20, 21. I ≈øhould now come to the next particular, were it not that ≈øtil I find another thing, which the factious fir≈øt, and others next, di≈øta≈øte and ≈øleight too much. For though ≈øome ≈øticke not to affirme, that it is aThis they affirme, becau≈øe the Commandement ≈øaith, Six da ‚Ä¢ es „Äà‚óä„Äâ on ≈øhalt labour. breach of the fourth Commandement, and ≈øo a ≈øinne, to make more Holy Dayes than one in ≈øeven: yet ≈øhall they never be able to prove why it ≈øhould be a ≈øinne rather now than heretofore. For ≈øhall the Iewes be no tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors of the Law, though they have more daies than their weekly Sabbath; and mu≈øt the Chri≈øtian offend in con≈øecrating dayes be≈øide the Sunday? For ≈øome, I grant, they were: but for other ≈øome againe they were appointed no otherwi≈øe than their Church ordained.E≈øter 9.21. For did they not every yeare ≈øolemnize and keepe holy the

Howbeit, for thy further ≈øatisfaction, take this al≈øo with thee; that God, who might challenge all our time for his worke, doth there ≈øhew that he is willing to remitWhich part is ordinarily ≈øix dayes, though not alwayes; as the Iewes them≈øelves do beare us witne≈ø≈øe. part of his right for thine owne workes: yet ≈øo, as he doth not re≈øtraine thee from doing publike ≈øervice to him, on any of tho≈øe dayes which the Church ≈øhall appoint: for except there be ≈øuper≈øtitious ends aymed at on the dayes ≈øet apart, this which I ≈øay mu≈øt needs be granted.

Why? becau≈øe the righteous ≈øhall be had in everla≈øting remembrance; as the P≈øalmi≈øt ≈øpeaketh:P≈øal. 112.6. and the memory of the ju≈øt be ble≈ø≈øed;Prov. 10.8. as the ≈øonne of the P≈øalmi≈øt hath expre≈ø≈øed. I would to God therefore that none but Puritanes were guilty of this ≈øinne in ≈øleighting ≈øuch Holy Dayes: others al≈øo cut off their e≈øteeme more than is meet. div.head: SECT. IV.
div.p: I Come now to a fourth particular; namely, that the people no way hinder their ≈øpiritual Fathers (whether Bi≈øhops or others) from going on cheerfully in their offices: for if through default of their flocke they goe on Gementes, it cannot in conclu≈øion but be wofully grievous unto tho≈øe over whom they watch, Heb. 13.17.
